content: Michelle Obama begins military advocacy FORT BRAGG, N.C. — The nation owes not only gratitude but tangible assistance to the nation’s military and their families, and she’ll make that a focus of her time in the White House, first lady Michelle Obama says. Underscoring her commitment to the plight of America’s military families, Mrs. Obama used a trip to Fort Bragg as a stage for her first television interviews since the inauguration. One with ABC’s “Good Morning America” aired Friday. In the interview she said she wanted military families to know they have a friend in the White House. “It hurts. It hurts,” Mrs. Obama said of hearing about military families on food stamps. “These are people who are willing to send their loved ones off to, perhaps, give their lives — the ultimate sacrifice. But yet, they’re living back at home on food stamps. It’s not right, and it’s not where we should be as a nation.” Full article at > Army Times >http://www.armytimes.com/news/2009/03/ap_firstlady_031309/
reply: Michelle Obama begins military advocacy FORT BRAGG, N.C. — The nation owes not only gratitude but tangible assistance to the nation’s military and their families, and she’ll make that a focus of her time in the White House, first lady Michelle Obama says. Underscoring her commitment to the plight of America’s military families, Mrs. Obama used a trip to Fort Bragg as a stage for her first television interviews since the inauguration. One with ABC’s “Good Morning America” aired Friday. In the interview she said she wanted military families to know they have a friend in the White House. “It hurts. It hurts,” Mrs. Obama said of hearing about military families on food stamps. “These are people who are willing to send their loved ones off to, perhaps, give their lives — the ultimate sacrifice. But yet, they’re living back at home on food stamps. It’s not right, and it’s not where we should be as a nation.” Full article at > Army Times >http://www.armytimes.com/news/2009/03/ap_firstlady_031309/
title: Michelle Obama begins military advocacy

It hurts,” Mrs. Obama said of hearing about military families on food stamps. “These are people who are willing to send their loved ones off to, perhaps, give their lives — the ultimate sacrifice. But yet, they’re living back at home on food stamps. If he did that, he would have to give it to all the Feds, including Congress. How about a change in base pay? That's a seperate system. They really need to re-evaluate the base pay rate for all military career fields. I suggest they use KBR and Blackwater as their baseline. That way cooks, transportation specialists, and military police will have a base pay of 100K. I'm sure that Congress will support it.

content: quote: Originally posted by nspreitler: quote: Originally posted by outlaws93: [QUOTE]Which Congressman from Southern Illinois? use that vast military experiences to find out who... Jerry Costello is in office now for the 12th District and has been since 88. John Shimkus has been in office for the 19th District since 03; he was preceded by Phelps who was only in office for four years. Glenn Poshard was before him for 10 years. That covers both Southern Illinois distrcits for the last 20 years. I would have to guess you are talking about Melvin Price who was before Costello and he was in Congress from 1944 until his death 1988, but that was more than a few years ago.
quote: Originally posted by nspreitler: quote: Originally posted by outlaws93: [QUOTE]Which Congressman from Southern Illinois? use that vast military experiences to find out who...
reply: Jerry Costello is in office now for the 12th District and has been since 88. John Shimkus has been in office for the 19th District since 03; he was preceded by Phelps who was only in office for four years. Glenn Poshard was before him for 10 years. That covers both Southern Illinois distrcits for the last 20 years. I would have to guess you are talking about Melvin Price who was before Costello and he was in Congress from 1944 until his death 1988, but that was more than a few years ago.
title: Michelle Obama begins military advocacy

reply: Jerry Costello is in office now for the 12th District and has been since 88. John Shimkus has been in office for the 19th District since 03; he was preceded by Phelps who was only in office for four years. Glenn Poshard was before him for 10 years. That covers both Southern Illinois distrcits for the last 20 years. I would have to guess you are talking about Melvin Price who was before Costello and he was in Congress from 1944 until his death 1988, but that was more than a few years ago.
title: Michelle Obama begins military advocacy

content: Michelle Obama begins military advocacy FORT BRAGG, N.C. — The nation owes not only gratitude but tangible assistance to the nation’s military and their families, and she’ll make that a focus of her time in the White House, first lady Michelle Obama says. Underscoring her commitment to the plight of America’s military families, Mrs. Obama used a trip to Fort Bragg as a stage for her first television interviews since the inauguration. One with ABC’s “Good Morning America” aired Friday. In the interview she said she wanted military families to know they have a friend in the White House. “It hurts. It hurts,” Mrs. Obama said of hearing about military families on food stamps. “These are people who are willing to send their loved ones off to, perhaps, give their lives — the ultimate sacrifice. But yet, they’re living back at home on food stamps. It’s not right, and it’s not where we should be as a nation.” Full article at > Army Times >http://www.armytimes.com/news/2009/03/ap_firstlady_031309/

content: quote: Originally posted by shuman14: quote: “It hurts. It hurts,” Mrs. Obama said of hearing about military families on food stamps. “These are people who are willing to send their loved ones off to, perhaps, give their lives — the ultimate sacrifice. But yet, they’re living back at home on food stamps. It’s not right, and it’s not where we should be as a nation.” Great, then convince your husband to give us all a 15% across the board cost of living increase. He can't give a 15% COLA. If he did that, he would have to give it to all the Feds, including Congress. How about a change in base pay? That's a seperate system. They really need to re-evaluate the base pay rate for all military career fields. I suggest they use KBR and Blackwater as their baseline. That way cooks, transportation specialists, and military police will have a base pay of 100K. I'm sure that Congress will support it.
